case_vignette: An 8-year-old male presents with 1 week of itchy blisters on the ears. He just recently returned from spring break with his family. He denies using any particular products on the ears before the rash. He says that this has occurred yearly for the last several years, always around the same time. He denies proximal muscle weakness. He denies flaking in the scalp.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have itchy blisters on my ears that started a week ago.
Got it. Have you experienced these blisters before? Or is this the first time?
Yes, I get these blisters every year around the same time.
Do you have any other medical conditions or take any medications regularly?
No, I don't have any other medical conditions or take regular medications.
Do any of your family members have a history of similar skin conditions?
The case vignette does not provide information about my family's medical history, so I can't answer that.
I understand, thank you for your response. Based on your symptoms and medical history, I believe you may be experiencing **contact dermatitis**.
